Package org.bluezoo.gumdrop.auth

Class LDAPRealm

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.bluezoo.gumdrop.auth.LDAPRealm
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Realm
    public class LDAPRealm
extends java.lang.Object
implements Realm
    LDAP-backed Realm for authenticating users against a directory server.

    This realm connects to an LDAP server (Active Directory, OpenLDAP, etc.) to authenticate users and check role membership. It supports both simple bind authentication and search-then-bind patterns.

    Configuration

    
 <realm class="org.bluezoo.gumdrop.auth.LDAPRealm">
   <host>ldap.example.com</host>
   <port>389</port>
   <baseDN>dc=example,dc=com</baseDN>
   <bindDN>cn=service,dc=example,dc=com</bindDN>
   <bindPassword>secret</bindPassword>
   <userFilter>(uid={0})</userFilter>
   <roleAttribute>memberOf</roleAttribute>
 </realm>

    Authentication Flow

    1. Bind to LDAP using service account (bindDN/bindPassword)
    2. Search for user using userFilter with username substituted
    3. Re-bind as the found user DN with their password
    4. If successful, user is authenticated

    TLS Support

    • LDAPS (port 636): Set secure="true" and configure sslContext
    • STARTTLS: Set startTLS="true" and configure sslContext
    Author:
    Chris Burdess

      • forSelectorLoop

        public Realm forSelectorLoop​(SelectorLoop loop)
        Description copied from interface: Realm
        Returns a Realm instance bound to the specified SelectorLoop.

        This method allows realm implementations that need to make client connections (e.g., LDAP, database) to share the same event loop as the server using them. This ensures proper thread affinity and efficient I/O multiplexing.

        For synchronous realms that don't require client connections (like BasicRealm), this method should simply return this.

        For async realms, this method should return a new (or pooled) instance with a client connection bound to the specified loop. The returned realm may be a lightweight wrapper that shares configuration with the original but has its own connection state.

        Specified by:
        forSelectorLoop in interface Realm
        Parameters:
        loop - the SelectorLoop to bind to
        Returns:
        a realm instance bound to the specified loop

      • getSupportedSASLMechanisms

        public java.util.Set<SASLMechanism> getSupportedSASLMechanisms()
        Description copied from interface: Realm
        Returns the set of SASL mechanisms this realm supports.

        Servers should call this method when building their capability response (e.g., IMAP CAPABILITY, SMTP EHLO AUTH, POP3 CAPA SASL) and only advertise mechanisms that the realm supports.

        The relationship between mechanisms and realm methods:

        • SASLMechanism.PLAIN, SASLMechanism.LOGIN - require Realm.passwordMatch(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)
        • SASLMechanism.CRAM_MD5 - requires Realm.getCramMD5Response(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)
        • SASLMechanism.DIGEST_MD5 - requires Realm.getDigestHA1(java.lang.String, java.lang.String)
        • SASLMechanism.SCRAM_SHA_256 - requires Realm.getScramCredentials(java.lang.String)
        • SASLMechanism.EXTERNAL - requires Realm.userExists(java.lang.String)
        • SASLMechanism.OAUTHBEARER - requires Realm.validateBearerToken(java.lang.String)
        Specified by:
        getSupportedSASLMechanisms in interface Realm
        Returns:
        an unmodifiable set of supported SASL mechanisms

      • passwordMatch

        public boolean passwordMatch​(java.lang.String username,
                             java.lang.String password)
        Description copied from interface: Realm
        Verifies that the given password matches the stored credentials for the user. This is the preferred authentication method as it allows realm implementations to use password hashing without exposing plaintext passwords.
        Specified by:
        passwordMatch in interface Realm
        Parameters:
        username - the username to authenticate
        password - the password to verify
        Returns:
        true if the password matches, false if the password is incorrect or user doesn't exist

      • getDigestHA1

        public java.lang.String getDigestHA1​(java.lang.String username,
                                     java.lang.String realmName)
        Description copied from interface: Realm
        Computes the H(A1) hash for HTTP Digest Authentication (RFC 2617). H(A1) = MD5(username:realm:password) This allows realm implementations to either: - Store plaintext passwords and compute H(A1) on demand - Pre-compute and store H(A1) hashes directly (more secure)
        Specified by:
        getDigestHA1 in interface Realm
        Parameters:
        username - the username
        realmName - the realm name used in the digest computation
        Returns:
        the H(A1) hash as a lowercase hex string, or null if user doesn't exist

public java.lang.String getPassword​(java.lang.String username)

        Description copied from interface: Realm
        Returns the password for the given user, or null if the user does not exist.
        Specified by:
        getPassword in interface Realm
        Parameters:
        username - the username
        Returns:
        the plaintext password, or null if the user does not exist

      • isUserInRole

        public boolean isUserInRole​(java.lang.String username,
                            java.lang.String role)
        Description copied from interface: Realm
        Indicates whether the specified user has the given role.

        This is a standard security concept used for authorization decisions. Role names are defined by the application (e.g., "admin", "user", "ftp-read", "ftp-write").

        Specified by:
        isUserInRole in interface Realm
        Parameters:
        username - the username to check
        role - the role name to check for
        Returns:
        true if the user has the specified role, false otherwise

      • userExists

        public boolean userExists​(java.lang.String username)
        Description copied from interface: Realm
        Checks whether a user exists in this realm. This is useful for authentication mechanisms that need to verify user existence without checking a password (e.g., certificate-based auth).
        Specified by:
        userExists in interface Realm
        Parameters:
        username - the username to check
        Returns:
        true if the user exists, false otherwise
